descriptionSet.description: On this advertisement poster from Lactogen Baby Food, a manifestation of the Baby Krishna, called Makhan Chor, is pictured, sitting under a tree playing the flute. Next to him, two Gopis and a couple of cows can be seen as well. The depiction of Krishna is customized with flowers.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Lactogen The best baby food

description-en: On this advertisement poster from Lactogen Baby Food, a manifestation of the Baby Krishna, called Makhan Chor, is pictured, sitting under a tree playing the flute. Next to him, two Gopis and a couple of cows can be seen as well. The depiction of Krishna is customized with flowers. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It is clear from the extant examples that certain kinds of images lend themselves best to such embellishment, performed itself as an act of devotion. These types of images enable a customization to fit the needs and devotional aspirations of the consumer, and are, by and large, images of gods (whether in advertisements or not) and subjects related to nationalism or equivalent imagery for group identity. The “passionate devotionalism” we have recognized before is played out in its most tangible form here. (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)

related literature: Braudel, Fernand 1981. "The Structures of Everyday Life". London: Collins. (gs)
related literature: de Certeau, Michel 1984. "The Practices of Everyday Life" . Berkeley: University of California Press. (gs)

related hyperlink: Freitag, Sandria B. 2010. "Consumption and identity: Imagining ‘Everyday Life’ Through Popular Visual Culture" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/96/index.html, last accessed 2011-04-23. (gs)
